Due to a formula error that was discovered in August for Longs Peak and Wild Basin traffic counts, a correction was made for all months in 2011. These formula corrections resulted in overall visitation at Wild Basin increasing 1,344 for the January-July period, and Longs Peak increasing 43,782 for January-July. Historical data cannot be changed, and previous years cannot be corrected. Therefore, direct comparisons to data in previous years are no longer possible for these two areas, nor for the overall total visits and total year-to-date figures at Rocky Mountain National Park. 

However, the overall percentage increase of these two locations is minor compared to main entrances in the park. Reflecting trends at main entrances, which is where the majority of park visitors access the park, can still be compared by looking at main entrance figures on the park visitation website.
Medano Pass continued to be closed due to flood damage and only reopened in late October 2012....hence the very low figure for this month
Lodging closed mid-month for the winter.

Old Fall River Road closed 10/14/11 for the season. Trail Ridge Road officially closed for the season 10/27/11 but did not open after 10/22 due to snow, and it was closed Columbus Day Weekend due to snow. Longs Peak Campground closed 10/11/11 for the winter for hazard tree mitigation (it is usually open year-round).

Rocky Mountain National Park is correcting and aligning its public use statistics procedures. Starting in January 2012, traffic is counted at Lumpy Ridge and Lily Lake on the park’s east side; regression formulas rather than counters are used for west side minor entrances; Sun Valley Road, a county road across from the Kawuneeche Visitor Center, is no longer counted as non-recreation visitation as this road is not administered by the park; and Hiker Shuttle riders and visitors who enter the park on horseback are counted as recreational visits. These changes will help correctly align the park’s Recreational and Non-Recreational visitation. 

Due to our visitation calculations changing this year, the only way to compare this year to previous year's visitation is to look at the major entrance stations.  Comparing other statistics would be inaccurate.

A Person Per Vehicle (PPV) study is being conducted from December 2011 through October 2012 to determine whether currently-used multipliers are still correct or should be adjusted.

The week of 9-12-13, the northern portion of Colorado's Front Range experienced an historic and devastating flood. The Estes Park area was one of the hardest hit, affecting all highways that access the community, businesses, homes, and services. The main access roads to the east side of the park, highways 34 and 36, were closed from September 12 through October. 
In the park, many bridges, trails, and some roads were damaged. Repairs started immediately, but recreation visitation was tremendously affected (-51.9%). Most of the park reopened by 9/26/13, but Aspenglen and Longs Peak campgrounds, and Old Fall River Road closed for the season as a result of flood damage.
Federal Shut down Octber 1-16, 2013....Figures given represent 1/2 of the Month of October in actuality.
Government shutdown left the park closed from October 1-17, 2013. Visitation stats will be very low for the month.

The US government experienced a shutdown in early October. The State of Colorado funded a few days of park operations before the federal government reopened. RMNP was shutdown 10/1 through 10/11/13. Additionally, the Estes Park area, which is the gateway community on the east side of the park, continues to experience damaged roads, businesses, homes, and interruptions to services as a result of the September 2013 flood. In the park, many bridges, trails, and some roads were damaged. Repairs stared immediately but recreation visitation was tremendously affected (-69.9%). Most of the park reopened by 9/26/13, but Aspenglen and Longs Peak campgrounds, and Old Fall River Road closed for the season as a result of flood damage. Trail Ridge Road closed for the season 10/22/13.
All concession facilities closed for winter season.
The east side of the park, including the gateway community of Estes Park, continues to recover from the floods in September.

The U.S. Government experienced a shutdown from 10 pm MST Friday, December 21, 2018, through 10 pm MST Friday, January 25, 2019. During the shutdown:
• Some entrances and trailheads were open during the shutdown including Lily Lake, Longs Peak, and Lumpy Ridge.  All RMNP visitor centers and facilities were closed during the shutdown except for Fall River Visitor Center, which is located outside the park boundary and was operated by the park’s Friends Group, the Rocky Mountain Conservancy.
•  Due to road conditions from snowfall late Saturday, December 23 and blowing and drifting snow and ice combined with the inability to snowplow, sand or otherwise maintain the roads, gates were closed on December 24 past the Beaver Meadows Visitor Center on US 36, past the Fall River Entrance on US 34, past the Wild Basin Entrance on the Wild Basin Road and at the Grand Lake Entrance on US 34.  These entrances experienced walk-in visitors during the closure. The park is estimating an average parkwide of 500 walk-in visitors daily. For December this is 8 days (Monday, Dec 24, through Mon, Dec 31) x 500/day = 4000 walk-ins, and this estimate is added to the Beaver Meadows Entrance December count.

The park closed after January 5th due to the federal government shutdown and rockfall damage to the main park road. The park remained closed to the public through early February.

The U.S. Government experienced a shutdown from 10 pm MST Friday, December 21, 2018, through 10 pm MST Friday, January 25, 2019. During the shutdown
• Some entrances and trailheads were open during the shutdown including Lily Lake, Longs Peak, and Lumpy Ridge.  All RMNP visitor centers and facilities were closed during the shutdown except for Fall River Visitor Center, which is located outside the park boundary and was operated by the park’s Friends Group, the Rocky Mountain Conservancy. 
• Although the government shutdown continued through January 25, on January 12, Rocky Mountain National Park was able to fund basic services with revenue generated by recreation fees. National Park Service officials determined that by using Federal Land and Recreation Enhancement funds to bring back limited park maintenance staff to plow roads, clean restrooms, and remove trash, the park could restore accessibility to the park for visitors. After roads were plowed and sanded, park staff reopened roads on January 14 to their normal winter status.   
• For the time period in January that roads were not accessible by vehicles, the park is estimating an average parkwide of 200 walk-in visitors daily. For January this is 13 days (Tuesday, January 1, through Sunday, January 13) x 200/day = 2600 walk-ins, and this estimate is added to the Beaver Meadows Entrance January count.

April visitation can depend greatly on weather; it can be very cold and snowy – it can be warm and dry. This year, April in RMNP had several snowstorms. Trails and roads were snowy much of the month. However there was also a lot of nice weather. Bear Lake Road had Restricted Vehicle Access several weekend days.

Weather in the spring can have a great affect on visitation. May saw several snowstorms, rain, and a colder, later spring. Trail Ridge Road opened later than planned; it was scheduled to open on May 24 but did not open until June 6 due to wintry weather and conditions.

The first part of June was generally more wintry than usual, including snow and unseasonably colder temperatures. Trail Ridge Road opened for the season on June 5, rather than May 24 as scheduled, due to snow. Trails are typically snowy in June, especially higher trails, but this year they were even snowier. 
Trail Ridge Road was closed because of a late spring snowstorm starting the afternoon of June 21 and reopened on June 25. 
Old Fall River Road opened later than usual, in July, due to wintry conditions.
All roads and facilities were open in July, although there was quite a lot of roadwork both in RMNP and the local areas. Very seasonal weather, with frequent afternoon showers.
Very seasonal weather in RMNP in August. Roadwork on Trail Ridge Road and Bear Lake Road. Plus there was roadwork in Estes Park and Highway 7 south of Estes, and Highway 34 south of Grand Lake.

December had some very wintry weather, but also saw a lot of visitors.
The number of buses is a total for all entrances; a breakout of entrances is not available. The number of bus passengers is an estimate; the actual number is not available due to complications with the new cash register system. 
A year ago, the U.S. Government experienced a shutdown from 10 pm MST Friday, December 21, 2018, through 10 pm MST Friday, January 25, 2019. In December during the shutdown, RMNP experienced winter weather conditions and an inability to snowplow and grade main park roads, so gates were closed Dec 24-31, 2018. The park did estimate walk-in and minor entrance visitation during this time.

Statewide stay at home order issued on March 25th through April 26th to slow the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
Park facilities closed in mid-March, full park cclosed on 3/26 due to Covid-19 pandemic.

At the request of the local health department, RMNP closed at 7 pm  Friday, March 20, 2020. It closed to all park visitors 24-hours a day/7-days a week and there was no access permitted to Rocky Mountain National Park until the park began phased reopening on May 27, 2020.

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, at the request of the local health department and local officials to increase park access while providing the public a reasonable opportunity to comply with health guidelines, the park temporarily implemented a Timed Entry System effective June 4 to manage numbers and flow of vehicles coming into the park. A reservation is required to enter all areas of RMNP, including Trail Ridge Road (US Hwy 34), when arriving by vehicle between the hours of 6 am and 5 pm.

The timed entry permit system allocates approximately 60 percent of the park’s maximum parking capacity which works out to 13,500 visitors per day, or 4,800 vehicles. Due to the number of visitors who enter outside the reservation system, our actual visitation this month is approximately 75 percent of the maximum parking capacity.  

Major road construction is occurring on a 3-mile section of US 36 just west of Bear Lake Road junction to east of Deer Ridge Junction. This section of road is closed from 7 pm to 7 am Sunday nights through Friday mornings.

Some major events occurred in September and October in Rocky Mountain National Park, including historic wildfires, the covid pandemic, the end of the temporary Timed Entry system on October 13, and some significant and timely operations including the end of season for campgrounds and road construction. 
     Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, at the request of the local health department and local officials to increase park access while providing the public a reasonable opportunity to comply with health guidelines, the park temporarily implemented a Timed Entry System effective June 4 to manage numbers and flow of vehicles coming into the park. A reservation was required to enter all areas of RMNP, including Trail Ridge Road (US Hwy 34), when arriving by vehicle between the hours of 6 am and 5 pm. The Timed Entry system allocated approximately 60 percent of the park’s maximum parking capacity which worked out to approximately 13,500 visitors per day, or 4,800 vehicles. The Timed Entry system ended on October 13.
     In September, Glacier Basin Campground closed for the season 9/15/20. Major road construction occurred on a 3-mile section of US 36 just west of Bear Lake Road junction to east of Deer Ridge Junction. This section of road closed portions of weekdays for roadwork.

Park: Black Canyon of the Gunnison NP
Comments: No bus tours due to Covid-19

Group campsites closed due to COVID-19.
Two campsites closed for entire month due to storm damage.
Lodge and campground closed earlier than normal due to COVID.

Some major events occurred in October in RMNP, including historic wildfires, the covid pandemic, the end of the temporary Timed Entry system on Oct 13, and some significant and timely operations including the end of season for campgrounds and road construction. The Timed Entry system, which allocated approximately 60% of the park’s maximum parking capacity which worked out to approximately 13,500 visitors per day, or 4,800 vehicles, ended Oct 13. 
Construction work continued on US 36 between Bear Lake Road Junction and Deer Ridge Junction. Moraine Park Campground switched from summer to winter operations on Oct. 14. 
The Cameron Peak Wildfire caused closures in many areas of the NW, N, & NE areas of RMNP including Old Fall River Rd. These closures began in mid-August. RMNP was closed due to the East Troublesome Wildfire 10/21/2020 through 11/5/2020. Due to the East Troublesome Fire, the Town of Grand Lake was evacuated the night of Wed, Oct 21, and the Town of Estes Park began evacuations on Thurs, Oct 22. Both towns remained evacuated for several days. When the entire park closed on Oct 22 due to the East Troublesome Fire, major snowstorms and continued winter weather conditions at higher elevations followed. Because of these conditions, when the park reopened on Nov 6, Trail Ridge Road did not reopen for through travel and officially closed for the season on Nov 17. Approx 30,000 acres or 9% of RMNP have been impacted by the two fires. Some areas of the park remain closed.

Park: Black Canyon of the Gunnison NP
Comments: No bus tours due to COVID. Outdoor only VC access due to COVID

RMNP was closed due to the East Troublesome Wildfire 10/21/2020 through 11/5/2020. When the park reopened on Nov 6, reopened areas were on the east side of the park and included roads, parking areas and trails in Wild Basin, Longs Peak, Lily Lake, Twin Sisters, Lumpy Ridge, and US 34 through the Fall River Entrance. On Nov 14, additional areas were reopened, including the Beaver Meadows Entrance Station.
The East Inlet Trail and the East Shore Trail on the west side of Rocky Mountain National Park reopened on Nov 13. All other west side areas, including the Grand Lake Entrance, remained closed to all use for the month of November.
Moraine Park Campground would have been open to winter camping, but was closed all month. Many backcountry areas were closed to camping also.
High numbers for Lily Lake and Longs Peak are likely due to large areas of the park being closed due to the wildfires, plus milder weather and visitors wishing to get outside (Covid).
The ongoing road construction project between Beaver Meadows Entrance Station and Deer Ridge Junction resumed with delays.

Park: Black Canyon of the Gunnison NP
Comments: North Rim Ranger Station closed in both the inside and outdoor contact station for entire month of Nov. South Rim Entrance Station closed for Nov. also.

RMNP was closed due to the East Troublesome Wildfire 10/21/2020 through 11/5/2020. Parts of the park began reopening on 11/6/20.
12/10/20 US Highway 34 from the Grand Lake Entrance to the Colorado River Trailhead reopened; Trail Ridge Road is closed at the Colorado River Trailhead for the winter. Several trails and other secondary park roads also reopened on 12/10/20 and 12/22/20, although some trails remain closed due to the fires. 
The Fire Ban that was put in place 8/14/20 was lifted. 
High numbers for Lily Lake and Longs Peak are likely due to large areas of the park being closed due to the wildfires, plus milder weather and visitors wishing to get outside (Covid).
